titlestmt.titleproper: Free Library of Philadelphia collection of letters and manuscripts of literary figures 1761-1973
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

publicationstmt.publisher: Free Library of Philadelphia, Rare Book Department

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Free Library of Philadelphia collection of letters and manuscripts of literary figures
did.repository: Free Library of Philadelphia, Rare Book Department

bioghist.p: The Free Library of Philadelphia was founded in 1891 as the city's first public library system. Its Rare Book Department, among the largest in American public libraries, exists to serve the people of Philadelphia, as well as the students, scholars, and researchers who use its collections. The Rare Book Department's holding span 5000 years, from cuneiform tablets to 20th century literary manuscripts. Among the many collecting areas of the department are incunabula, American, European, and Oriental manuscripts, art and artist's papers, children's books and manuscripts, manuscripts and correspondence of American and British authors, examples of calligraphy, and Pennsylvania German fraktur. The Rare Book Department has major collections of Oliver Goldsmith, Charles Dickens, Edgar Allan Poe, Horace editions, Beatrix Potter, Arthur Rackham, and Robert Lawson.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection primarily composed of autograph letters, manuscripts, typescripts, and fragments of literary works. Significantly represented authors include James Branch Cabell, Joseph Conrad, Alexander Dumas, Oliver Goldsmith, Edgar Allan Poe, Ezra Pound, Agnes Repplier, George Bernard Shaw, and Mark Twain. Other authors represented include Wilkie Collins, Arthur Conan Doyle, Thomas Dixon, John Keats, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Robert Louis Stevenson, Algernon Swinburne, Alfred Tennyson, William Makepeace Thackeray, and Oscar Wilde. Manuscripts in the collection include Conrad's Victory and Under Western Eyes; Thomas Dixon's The Clansman; Elizabeth Drinker Bowen's Lion and the Throne and Adventures of a Biographer; and Wilkie Collins' The Dead Alive, The First Officer's Confession, and Royal Love. Ezra Pound materials include correspondence to Carl Gatter and Elsie Gatter and to Miss Margaret Doolittle from Ezra and Dorothy Pound; photographs of Wyncote and of students at Cheltenham Military Academy (including Ezra Pound); and other papers.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
